speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the wrist pain you're experiencing, when did it start and what activities make it worse? Have you had any recent injuries or traumas to the wrist area?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about three months ago, and it's been bothering me on and off since then. I've noticed it gets worse when I'm holding my baby, like when I'm feeding him or carrying him around, and it also hurts when I try to grip things tightly. I did fall on my outstretched hand about six months ago, but I didn't think much of it at the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: That fall could be relevant, even if it was six months ago. Can you describe the pain you're feeling - is it a sharp pain, a dull ache, or more of a tingling sensation? And does the pain radiate to any other parts of your hand or arm?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's mostly a dull ache, but sometimes it can be a sharp pain, especially when I'm lifting my baby or trying to open jars. The pain also seems to radiate up to my elbow, which can be really uncomfortable. Applying an ice pack helps to alleviate the pain somewhat, but it always seems to come back."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's helpful to know, the radiation of pain to the elbow could indicate a nerve issue. Have you experienced any numbness or tingling in your fingers or hand, and does the pain worsen at night or is it more of a problem during the day when you're active? REQUEST TEST: EMG

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: The normal EMG results suggest that there may not be a significant nerve damage issue. Can you tell me more about your daily activities and occupation, are you involved in any repetitive tasks or motions that could be contributing to the wrist pain? And have you noticed any swelling or redness in the affected area?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm a full-time mom right now, so I'm always lifting, carrying, and feeding my baby, which can be repetitive and strenuous on my hands and wrists. I haven't noticed any significant swelling or redness, but my wrist does feel a bit tender to the touch at times. I've been taking ibuprofen as needed to help manage the pain, but I'm worried that it's not just going to go away on its own."

speaker: Doctor
text: The repetitive motions of caring for your baby could definitely be exacerbating the issue. Have you noticed any clicking or snapping sounds when you move your wrist, and are there any specific positions or movements that make the pain better or worse? REQUEST TEST: Wrist_X-Ray

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: The normal X-ray results suggest that there may not be a fracture or obvious bone issue. Can you tell me more about any other symptoms you're experiencing, such as weakness or fatigue in your hand or arm, and have you noticed any difficulty with fine motor tasks like buttoning shirts or typing? REQUEST TEST: Arthrograms_of_Wrist

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: The normal arthrogram results suggest that there may not be a significant issue with the ligaments or joint space. Can you tell me more about when the pain typically occurs, is it constant or does it come and go, and are there any specific times of the day when it's worse, such as in the morning or evening? REQUEST TEST: MRI_of_Wrist

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: With all these normal test results, I'm starting to think that the issue might be related to the repetitive strain from caring for your baby. Can you tell me more about how you're lifting and carrying your baby, and if you've noticed any difference in the pain when you use a different lifting technique or take regular breaks to rest your hands and wrists?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, that makes sense, I do lift my baby a lot throughout the day. I usually pick him up with one arm, cradling him in my elbow and forearm, and sometimes I'll switch arms if I need to do something with the other hand. I haven't really thought about changing my lifting technique, but now that you mention it, maybe I should try to distribute the weight more evenly or take more breaks to rest my hands. It's just hard when he's crying and needs to be picked up right away, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text: I understand the challenge of caring for a baby, it can be tough to prioritize your own comfort when they need attention. Have you noticed any difference in the pain when you're not lifting or carrying your baby, for example, when you're sitting still or sleeping, does the pain persist or does it subside? REQUEST TEST: Ultrasound_of_Wrist

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

speaker: Doctor
text: With all these normal test results, I'm starting to think that the issue might be related to tendinitis or a repetitive strain injury. Can you tell me more about any activities you've done in the past that may have put strain on your wrists, and have you tried any exercises or stretches to help alleviate the pain? REQUEST TEST: Tendonitis_Screening

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Positive for tendonitis, specifically De Quervain's tenosynovitis, indicated by tenderness over the radial styloid and a positive Finkelstein's test.

speaker: Doctor
text: The positive test results for De Quervain's tenosynovitis explain the tenderness and pain you've been experiencing. Can you tell me more about your willingness to try conservative treatments, such as physical therapy or wrist splints, to help manage the condition, and are you open to exploring other options if needed?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm definitely willing to try conservative treatments, I'd rather not jump straight into anything more invasive if I can help it. Physical therapy sounds like a good option, and I've heard wrist splints can be really helpful for this type of condition. I just want to be able to take care of my baby without being in pain all the time, so I'm open to trying whatever will work best."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's great to hear that you're open to conservative treatments. Given the diagnosis of De Quervain's tenosynovitis, I think a combination of physical therapy and a wrist splint could be very effective in managing your symptoms. Can you tell me more about your daily routine and how you think we can modify it to reduce the strain on your wrists, and would you be willing to keep a pain journal to track your progress and identify any activities that may be triggering flare-ups?

speaker: Patient
text: "Modifying my daily routine might be a bit challenging, but I'm willing to try. I think one thing that could help is finding alternative ways to carry my baby, like using a baby carrier or asking my partner for help more often. I'd also be happy to keep a pain journal to track my progress and see if there are any specific activities that make the pain worse. It might be helpful to identify patterns and adjust my routine accordingly. Can you give me some guidance on what kind of information I should be tracking in the pain journal?"

speaker: Doctor
text: That's a great attitude to have, being willing to modify your daily routine to reduce strain on your wrists. For the pain journal, I'd like you to track the time of day when you experience pain, the activities you were doing before the pain started, and the severity of the pain on a scale of 1 to 10. Also, note any factors that seem to relieve the pain, such as rest or applying an ice pack. Can you commit to keeping this journal for at least two weeks to help us identify patterns and adjust your treatment plan accordingly?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, I can definitely commit to keeping a pain journal for two weeks. That sounds like a really helpful way to track my symptoms and identify any patterns. I'll make sure to write down the time of day, what I was doing before the pain started, and how severe it is. I'll also note if anything helps relieve the pain, like rest or ice packs. Do you want me to bring the journal with me to our follow-up appointments so we can review it together?"

speaker: Doctor
text: That's exactly what I'd like you to do, bring the journal to our follow-up appointments so we can review it together and adjust your treatment plan as needed. Now, considering we've discussed conservative treatments and you're willing to try them, I'd like to summarize your condition and create a personalized plan. Can you confirm that you have no other questions or concerns about your diagnosis or the proposed treatment before we proceed?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't have any other questions or concerns at this time. I feel like we've discussed everything thoroughly and I'm comfortable with the plan to try conservative treatments. I'm just looking forward to getting some relief from the pain and being able to take care of my baby without it bothering me. Can you tell me what the next steps are and when I should follow up with you again?"

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'm glad we've covered everything and you're comfortable with the plan. The next step would be to start physical therapy and use a wrist splint as we discussed. I'll also prescribe you some medication to help manage the pain and inflammation. Let's schedule a follow-up appointment for two weeks from now to review your progress and adjust the treatment plan if needed. In the meantime, don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. DIAGNOSIS READY: De Quervain's Tenosynovitis"
